intro: Plagiobothrys hirtus var. figuratus, commonly known as the hairy stem buttercup, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is characterized by its hairy stems and small, yellow flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant typically grows in moist, open habitats such as meadows and stream banks. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often covered with fine hairs, contributing to its distinctive appearance. The species is part of the tribe Cardueae and is known for its ecological importance in supporting pollinators.
